guide.conclusion: This project demonstrates how to amplify a signal from a microphone and use that signal to switch a transistor on and off. The transistor in turn is used to drive some LEDs. Circuits like this are very popular among hobbyists, and are often referred to as "light organs."

flags.title: Weekend Project
flags.text: This project is part of RadioShack's The Great Create.

guide.introduction:
This simple, wearable circuit uses an operational amplifier (or "op-amp") chip to convert sound into light. An LM324 op-amp and a transistor boost input from a mini condenser microphone to light a series of LEDs. Watch it blink to the beat of your favorite music.

Check out more Weekend Projects.

This simple, wearable circuit uses an operational amplifier (or "op-amp") chip to convert sound into light. An LM324 op-amp and a transistor boost input from a mini condenser microphone to light a series of LEDs. Watch it blink to the beat of your favorite music.

Check out more Weekend Projects.

Relevant parts
  • Op-Amp chip, Quad, LM324
  • Capacitor, 1.0µF non-polarized electrolytic (capacitor code 105)
  • Capacitor, 0.1 µF ceramic (100 nF, capacitor code 104)
  • Microphone condenser element
  • Transistor, NPN, 2N4401
  • Resistor assortment, 500 piece
  • PC board, grid style, with 371 holes
  • Hookup wire, 22 gauge, multiple colors
  • Battery snap, 9V
  • Battery, 9V
  • Solder, lead-free
  • LED 5mm
Tools
  • Soldering Iron, 15-Watt
  • Wire cutter/stripper

lines.text: The electret microphone element is polarized, so be careful not to reverse the connections. The ground leg is the one with the 3 silver traces running to the case (second photo).

steps.title: Solder the mic, socket, and power

lines.text: Follow the schematic to connect all components, starting with the microphone, chip socket, and battery holder.
lines.text_raw: Follow the schematic to connect all components, starting with the microphone, chip socket, and battery holder.

lines.text: It is useful to strip some wire and create a power "bus" consisting of V+ and Ground (-) lines running down the underside of the board on opposite sides. Solder these to the red (+) and black (-) wires of the battery holder, respectively.
lines.text_raw: It is useful to strip some wire and create a power "bus" consisting of V+ and Ground (-) lines running down the underside of the board on opposite sides. Solder these to the red (+) and black (-) wires of the battery holder, respectively.

lines.text: On the schematic, the LN324 chip is drawn functionally, using two separate amplifier symbols (the triangles). Both of these  represent the same component, and you need only one connection each between Pin 4 and V+, and Pin 11 and Ground.

steps.title: Add the input stage resistors and capacitors

lines.text: When you are following a schematic, it's  useful to print it out and mark off each connection as you make it. Quite often your circuit board layout will not resemble the diagram, and so, doing this lets you know how much you have completed.

lines.text: In the second photo here, you can see most of the input stage components added. These are: Microphone, 3x 10kΩ resistors (Brown, Black, Orange, Gold), 2.2kΩ resistor (Red, Red, Red, Gold), 470kΩ resistor (Yellow, Violet, Yellow, Gold), 1µF capacitor and 01.µF capacitor.

lines.text: Plug the LM324 chip into the socket. Note the chip's orientation. With the notch pointing up, Pin 1 is top left corner, and the pins are numbered counter-clockwise.

lines.text: Power it up by inserting the batteries. If nothing starts smoking, that's a good sign!

lines.text: To check the output from the first amplifier, I hooked up an oscilloscope to the right hand leg of the 0.1µF capacitor. This showed a sound wave when I spoke - so far, so good!

steps.title: Add the the second stage resistors

lines.text: We're getting really close now.  Add the remaining resistors: 47kΩ ohm (Yellow, violet, orange, gold), 10kΩ ohm (Brown, black, orange, gold), 100Ω (Brown, black, brown, gold).

lines.text: Solder a connecting wire from chip Pin 7 to where you'll put the transistor, which we'll add in the next step.

lines.text: All that remains is to add the transistor and the LEDs.

lines.text: Finish up by connecting the transistor (note the orientation) and the LEDs, connected in series.
